titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James L. Weil Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 04:19

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Weil papers contain correspondence, production files and writings, records of the Elizabeth Press, printed and audiovisual materials, and personal papers. The collection is made up of twenty-one separate donations made by Weil from 1983 to 2005. The first several accessions consist exclusively of materials relating to publications by Weil, while later accessions, beginning with the October 1990 Acquisition, consist of larger groups of material including correspondence, production files, and other papers. Correspondence in the collection, which features letters from writers, journal editors, publishers, booksellers, the many libraries to which Weil made donations, and others, is thus spread over multiple accessions. It is either sorted roughly, into so-called letter general folders ("A"-"Z") or by date, or it is unsorted; the bulk of the letters are also still housed in original envelopes. Individual correspondents include: Bob Arnold of Longhouse Publishers & Booksellers, Cid Corman, Theodore Enslin, David Giannini, Lyman Gilmore, Henry Lyman, Simon Perchik, Felix Stefanile, Jack Stillinger, Pierre Ullman, and others. Correspondence can include enclosures, such as drafts of writings, photographs, and printed material. Most of the production files in the collection appear to relate to the limited edition chapbooks and printed keepsakes published by Weil under his own name (James L. Weil, Publisher) from the mid 1980s onward, though records relating to the Elizabeth Press (1963-1981) can also be found. The production files, which include correspondence, drafts, specifications, proofs, and printed versions, feature work by William Bronk, Cid Corman, Larry Eigner, Aleksis Rannit, Karl Shapiro, Felix Stefanile, and others. Printed materials include newspapers, journals, clippings, and offprints containing reviews and concerning literary matters such as modern fine printing and small press publishing.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 5 and 9 (reel-to-reel tapes): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 6 and 25 (audio and video cassettes): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The James L. Weil Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James L. Weil Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection has received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, identified by month and year of acquisition.

The finding aid for this collection was originally compiled from individual preliminary lists for each acquisition that were created at or around the time of receipt by the library. The preliminary lists were migrated to comply with current archival descriptive standards and merged into a single file in 2007-2008. As part of the migration, modifications were made to the formatting of individual lists; however, the content of the lists was neither modified nor verified. In January 2014, additional work was done on the collection to standardize the housing and description across acquisitions, and a single call number was assigned.

Former call numbers: Uncat Za Ms Weil, Uncat Za Ms 107, Uncat Za Ms 152, Uncat Za Ms 242, Uncat Za Ms 274, Uncat Za Ms 338, Uncat Za Ms 339, Uncat Za Ms 418, Uncat Za Ms 535, Uncat Za Ms 557, Uncat Za Ms 560, Uncat MSS 17, Uncat MSS 206, Uncat MSS 250, Uncat MSS 772 and Uncat Za File 708.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: James L. Weil (1929-2006)
bioghist.p: James L. Weil, born 15 June 1929 in New York to Morris, a financier, and Charlotte (Ullman) Weil, was a poet and publisher. He attended the University of Chicago (1950) and Oxford University (1954) before going to work for the Dialight Corporation (1954-1968). Weil founded the Elizabeth Press (1963-1981), an important publisher of American poetry in the 1960s and 1970s, and published limited edition chapbooks and keepsakes under his own name from 1985 onward. His authors include William Bronk (1918-1999), Cid Corman (1924-2004), Larry Eigner (1927-1996), Theodore Enslin (1925-2011), Felix Stefanile (1920-2009), and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The James L. Weil papers contain correspondence, production files and writings, records of the Elizabeth Press, printed and audiovisual materials, and personal papers. The collection is made up of twenty-one separate donations made by Weil from 1983 to 2005. The first several accessions consist exclusively of materials relating to publications by Weil, while later accessions, beginning with the October 1990 Acquisition, consist of larger groups of material including correspondence, production files, and other papers. Correspondence in the collection, which features letters from writers, journal editors, publishers, booksellers, the many libraries to which Weil made donations, and others, is thus spread over multiple accessions. It is either sorted roughly, into so-called letter general folders ("A" - "Z") or by date, or it is unsorted; the bulk of the letters are also still housed in original envelopes. Individual correspondents include: Bob Arnold of Longhouse Publishers & Booksellers, Cid Corman, Theodore Enslin, David Giannini, Lyman Gilmore, Henry Lyman, Simon Perchik, Felix Stefanile, Jack Stillinger, Pierre Ullman, and others. Correspondence can include enclosures, such as drafts of writings, photographs, and printed material. Most of the production files in the collection appear to relate to the limited edition chapbooks and printed keepsakes published by Weil under his own name (James L. Weil, Publisher) from the mid 1980s onward, though records relating to the Elizabeth Press (1963-1981) can also be found. The production files, which include correspondence, drafts, specifications, proofs, and printed versions, feature work by William Bronk, Cid Corman, Larry Eigner, Aleksis Rannit, Karl Shapiro, Felix Stefanile, and others. Printed materials include newspapers, journals, clippings, and offprints containing reviews and concerning literary matters such as modern fine printing and small press publishing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into twenty-one groupings: January 1983 Acquisition, April 1984 Acquisition, October 1984 Acquisition, February 1985 Acquisition, October 1985 Acquisition, January 1986 Acquisition, September 1986 Acquisition, January 1987 Acquisition, December 1987 Acquisition, June 1989 Acquisition, October 1990 Acquisition, January 1992 Acquisition, March 1993 Acquisition, December 1994 Acquisition, July 1997 Acquisition, April 1998 Acquisition, May 1998 Acquisition, February 2000 Acquisition, January 2002 Acquisition, May 2005 Acquisition, and September 2005 Acquisition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The January 1983 Acquisition consists of drafts, proofs, and other materials relating to publication of As David Danced by William Bronk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Former call number: Uncat Za Ms Weil.

did.unittitle: As David Danced , drafts, autograph manuscript and typescript, and proofs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The April 1984 Acquisition contains correspondence relating to As David Danced and various materials, including drafts and proofs, relating to publication of A Happiness In Shops by John Synge.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms Weil.

did.unittitle: A Happiness In Shops , draft, proofs, and printed version

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The October 1984 Acquisition contains various materials, including correspondence, drafts, proofs, and a printed version, relating to publication of Some People Think by James Laughlin.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms Weil.

did.unittitle: Some People Think , correspondence, drafts, proofs, and printed version

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The February 1985 Acquisition contains drafts of Equinox and other poems by William Bronk and other publication material relating to Equinox .

did.unittitle: Equinox , draft, typescript, proof, and printed version

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The October 1985 Acquisition contains material relating to editions of "To My Brother George" by John Keats.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 338.

did.unittitle: To My Brother George , correspondence, proofs, and other material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The January 1986 Acquisition consists of production files for publications of work by William Bronk, Larry Eigner, John Keats, John Pearlman, and Felix Stefanile. Materials include correspondence, research material, drafts, and page proofs.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms Weil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The September 1986 Acquisition consists of publication material relating to William Bronk's Holy Orders and The Untold .
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms Weil.

did.unittitle: Holy Orders , correspondence, draft, and proofs
The Untold , correspondence, draft, and proofs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The January 1987 Acquisition contains production files for George Spelvin by Spencer Brown and The Life and Winter Evening by William Bronk.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms Weil.

did.unittitle: George Spelvin , correspondence, drafts, corrected, and proof

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The December 1987 Acquisition contains production files, including correspondence, drafts, publisher's specifications, and proofs, relating to fifteen chapbooks and keepsakes issued by Weil during the mid 1980s.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 339.

arrangement.p: Organized into three subgroupings: Correspondence, Production Files, and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The January 1992 Acquisition includes correspondence, production files, and other material. Correspondence consists of letters to James Weil from writers, journal editors, publishers, booksellers, libraries, acknowledging gifts, and others, dating predominantly from 1990 and 1991, with one large file for Jack Stillinger. Production files include several folders for additional chapbooks by William Bronk and others. Other materials includes an audio tape of James Weil reading at the Library of Congress.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 242.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subgroupings: Correspondence, Production Files and Writings, Elizabeth Press Records, and Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The March 1993 Acquisition consists of correspondence, production files and writings, records of the Elizabeth Press, and printed and other material. Correspondence again features letters to Weil from writers, journal editors, publishers, booksellers, libraries, and others. Correspondence dates heavily from 1992, but there is some early personal correspondence and, in addition to incoming letters, there are scattered photocopies of outgoing letters from Weil to others. Production files include folders for work by William Bronk, Aleksis Rannit, and others, as well as proofs for Weil's Something Given: Very Selected Poems, 1964-1991 (1992). Printed materials include newspapers, journals, clippings, and offprints containing reviews and discussing literary matters such as modern fine printing and small press publishing.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 274.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs

arrangement.p: Organized into two subgroupings: Monthly Poems and Other Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The May 1998 Acquisition consists entirely of writings by Simon Perchik. The first subgroup consists of small numbers of poems written and organized by the months of the year, presented ("No. _ of 10 copies") in typescript, signed and with inscriptions from Perchik to Weil.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 560.

did.unittitle: "December Poems: To The Photographs of John R. Milton"

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subgroupings: Correspondence, Production Files, and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The February 2000 Acquisition includes correspondence, production files, and printed material by or relating to Weil. The correspondence, unsorted and largely still in envelopes, includes some scattered manuscript and printed material. There are letters from the many libraries to which Weil donated publications and from writers with whom he collaborated, including Cid Corman, Simon Perchik, Felix Stefanile, and Jack Stillinger, among others.
Former call number: Uncat MSS 17.

did.unittitle: For All We Know by William Bronk
Founding Fathers by James L. Weil
This living hand, now warm and capable by John Keats

accessrestrict.p: Box 25 (videocassettes): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subgroupings: Correspondence, Production Files, and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The January 2002 Acquisition also contains correspondence, production files, and other material. The correspondence, unsorted and largely still in envelopes, includes some enclosures, such as manuscripts, photographs, and printed ephemera. There are letters and cards from many ongoing collaborators, such as Jack Stillinger, as well as Theodore Enslin and Michael Peich.
Former call number: Uncat MSS 250.

Former call number: Uncat Za File 708.
